awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Improving Cloud Services by Exploiting Synchronized Clocks and Software Defined Flash
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale data centers provide the computational infrastructure that underlies the increasing use of cloud services (Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure, etc.).  Today's data centers exhibit properties of both loosely coupled distributed systems and tightly coupled supercomputers.  For example, networking infrastructure now mimics early supercomputers with low lantency and high bandwidth per link, high bisection bandwidth Fat-Tree topologies, and remote memory operations (e.g., RoCE).  The rapid increase in cloud computing motivates the desire to invest in increasing capabilities, and that the trend is to move further toward supercomputing-like capabilities.  Nonetheless, the scale of today's systems and services necessitates that many distributed systems properties remain, such as relatively high failure rates and the need for integrated reliable storage systems for transaction processing.

This project seeks to improve cloud services through the combined use of the IEEE Precision Time Protocol and Software Defined Flash to develop a high performance, reliable, cost-effective, transactional storage system.  A key aspect of this project is the development of a prototype distributed transactional system built on-top of a multi-version key-value Flash-based storage system.  The storage system exploits SSD write behavior to efficiently maintain multiple key versions that are time ordered based on a globally (within the data center) unique timestamp for each request and enables clients to make a local commit or abort decision. The proposed approach exploits both tightly synchronized clocks with < 1 microsecond skew and Software Defined Flash to eliminate or reduce overheads relative to other systems.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project all relate to the central theme of exploiting emerging trends in data centers, including: 1) precisely synchronized clocks, 2) user accessible non-volatile memory (e.g., FLASH or other NVRAM) to improve cloud services within data centers, 3) low latency RDMA, and 4) emergence of specialized architectures and use of GPUs for machine learning. A key focus is to develop a high performance, cost-effective, reliable transactional storage system. The longer-term research included caching, exploiting low latency messaging using RDMA and developing application specific accelerators.

Milana+Semel and the follow-on caching methods in Kairos provide a lightweight transactional storage system that reduces overhead and improves performance such that fewer servers may be required to support a given level of performance.  Our system achieves this using precise time, a multiversion SSD FLASH control software and optimistic concurrency control transactional key-value storage system. Overall, this can reduce energy consumption and total cost of ownership for data center providers or improve user performance for a given cost.

Results exploring RDMA for multi-tenant data center workloads shows that congestion control algorithms do not provide fairness for long flows, like those used in big data workloads. We overcome this with new designs that quick converge to fair bandwidth allocation so that long flows are not unduly penalized.  We also demonstrate performance isolation issues in current RDMA congestion control techniques.  Collectively these results provide a foundation for future work to create fair, secure and performant data center communication systems that can meet the needs of future applications in a multi-tenant cloud environment.

Our work on accelerating Markov Chain Monte Carlo solvers for Bayesian Inference is an important step to enable understandable inference where more than just end point results are desired.  Specifically, the proposed accelerator provides performance superior to GPUs and include support for computing result uncertainty.  Additionally, our proposed framework for evaluating statistical robustness of MCMC accelerators has influenced Intel and brings to the forefront the notion that computer architects need to take a broader view of what correct means for probabilistic workloads.

The work by undergraduate and graduate students on this project developed their understanding of concurrent systems and systems programming skills, while also broadening participation to underrepresented groups through support for one female student. Several students received either MS or PhD degrees for projects related to this award. Most of these students have gone on to full-time jobs in US technology industry.
